awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Resolving the Nature and Extent Archean Crustal Components in Southwestern Laurentia Using Hf and U-Pb Analysis of Zircon and Baddeleyite
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to resolve a long-standing controversy regarding the earliest evolution and deep structure of the Precambrian lithosphere of southwestern North America. This area is a globally important field laboratory for studies of the processes that form continents. Current debate has focused on the need to resolve the relative importance of accretion of juvenile arcs versus recycling of older crustal materials, and/or rift-related addition of mafic crust. The objectives of this project are to: 1) resolve the nature of the cryptic Archean and other pre-1.8 Ga lithospheric components in the Mojave Province and elucidate the timing and processes of their incorporation into an assembling 1.8-1.6 Ga orogenic system; 2) discover more definitive piercing points (relative to Australia, Antarctica, etc.) that can be used for supercontinent reconstructions of Nuna (1.8 Ga) and Rodina (1.0 Ga); and 3) provide a comprehensive basement provenance age template in support of the wide array of detrital zircon studies of sedimentary basins of all ages in the Southwest. The approach is to use U/Pb radiometric dating and Hf isotopic characterization of zircons from the oldest rocks in the Southwest. Pilot studies show that these rocks contain still older grains, whose history will be decipherable using these approaches. The research team will analyze inherited zircons from the oldest plutons, which act as probes what was being melted in the lower crust, and detrital zircons from the oldest metasedimentary rocks, which are an indication of eroding source regions and resulting sedimentary basin and depositional systems.

The project involves collaboration between PIs in U.S. academia, the USGS, and Australian collaborators from academia and the mineral industry. The combined datasets will be integrated with several decades of previous work by the PIs and with emerging new geophysical images from the NSF EarthScope experiment. The importance of the work will be a new integrated synthesis of the structure and evolution of the basement architecture of this part of the North American continent that will be useful for many subfields in the geosciences, including tectonics, deep time geologic history of our continent, ground-truth of geophysical interpretations of the subsurface, and applications for minerals exploration. The project also has a strong outreach component that integrates research and education via training of student geoscientists, including minority students, and working with the Parks for informal geoscience education of the public.

Intellectual Merit:  We proposed to resolve the nature of the long-recognized but poorly understood  pre-2.5 billion year old crust of the Mojave Province of southwestern U.S. The puzzle has been how to explain such old crust (and equally old mantle lithosphere) in the context of models for assembly of the southern part of our continent that took place 1.8 to 1.6 billion years ago. A second goal was to define possible tectonic connections between southwestern USA and other continents such as Australia, Antarctica, and South China within hypothesized Precambrian supercontinents called Nuna (at 1.8 billion) and Rodina (at 1.0 billion). Models for an Australian- Western US connection have been called the AUSWUS reconstructions and these have been hotly debated for the past twenty years.

 Broader Impacts: Research and student training took take place via a cross-institutional student research program involving completion of 3 PhD students, 3 MS students, and 1 BS Honors thesis. Wide dissemination occurred through publication of 11 peer reviewed journal articles (and 2 more in preparation) plus about 20 presentations at professional meetings as well as talks given to the general public. Open access of scientific results was enabled through the AZ LaserChron lab’s new “Geochron” initiative that links to Earthchem and EARTHTIME. Student training at the Arizona Laserchron laboratory provided analytical training for an additional 4 graduate and 4 undergraduate students exposed them to modern analytical techniques and applications. Understanding of such ancient geologic history remains of societal importance because old boundaries and provinces within our continent get reactivated by and affect the character of younger tectonic events such as volcanoes and earthquakes.

Transformative outcomes and unanticipated discoveries:  Several important outcomes are listed below. #1 was transformative, unanticipated, and has spurred a new controversy about the Mazatzal orogeny. #2 is transformative in resolving a several decade long controversy about the Mojave province. #3, #4, #5, and #6 are important advances in re-directing their fields of inquiry. #7 has further demonstrated the power of combined Hf and U-Pb dating for characterizing igneous and sedimentary basement rocks for both Proterozoic and Phanerozoic tectonic problems. #8 was transformative in demonstrating that reliable U-Pb ages and Hf isotope signatures can be generated for baddeleyite, thereby extending these powerful techniques to rocks of mafic and ultramafic compositions.   

                1) Mike Doe’s PhD research led to the discovery of a 1.5-1.47 Ga sedimentary succession (Yankee Joe Formation) and refined models for the AUSWUS supercontinent connection. 3 papers have been published and a fourth is in preparation (Doe et al., 2012; 2013; in prep.; and Jones et al., 2015).

                2) Mark Holland’s PhD work has resolved the “Mojave Problem” by showing that very ancient crust and mantle likely exist deep below the Mojave province, and the main signal of inherited pre-1.8 billion year old crust is from grains washed into metasedimentary rocks within what we now name the  Vishnu turbidite basin that was derived from Australian crust within the supercontinent of Nuna. The boundary between the Archean-cored Mojave and the younger accreted Yavapai province in Grand Canyon is interpreted as an imbricate middle crustal duplex zone (a plate tectonic train wreck; Holland et al., 2014; and in press).
